analyzed: gsum pa ni lus kyi gnas dang / chos kyi gnas yongs su gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The third is called “nirvāṇa” because the basis of the body and the basis of phenomena have been transformed.

original: bzhi pa ni sems can rnams la don mdzad pa'i rgyu dang / rkyen rang gi ngang  gis nye bar zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: bzhi pa ni sems can rnams la don mdzad pa'i rgyu dang / rkyen rang gi ngang  gis nye bar zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The fourth is called “nirvāṇa” because the causes and conditions for acting for the welfare of sentient beings have naturally subsided.

original: lnga pa ni de kho na nyid kyi mtshan nyid tha dad med pa mnyam pa nyid kyi chos kyi sku mngon sum du brnyes pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: lnga pa ni de kho na nyid kyi mtshan nyid tha dad med pa mnyam pa nyid kyi chos kyi sku mngon sum du brnyes pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The fifth is called “nirvāṇa” because the dharmakāya, the equality of phenomena that is the undifferentiated characteristic of reality, has been actualized.

original: drug pa ni 'khor ba dang / mya ngan las 'das pa la ngo bo nyid gnyis su med par thugs su chud pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: drug pa ni 'khor ba dang / mya ngan las 'das pa la ngo bo nyid gnyis su med par thugs su chud pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The sixth is called “nirvāṇa” because it realizes that saṃsāra and nirvāṇa are not two different natures.

original: bdun pa ni chos thams cad kyi rtsa ba thugs su chud nas rnam par dag pa mngon sum du gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: bdun pa ni chos thams cad kyi rtsa ba thugs su chud nas rnam par dag pa mngon sum du gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The seventh is called “nirvāṇa” because it realizes the root of all phenomena and directly perceives complete purity.

original: brgyad pa ni chos thams cad la skye ba med cing 'grag pa med par rnal 'byor legs par bsgoms pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: brgyad pa ni chos thams cad la skye ba med cing 'grag pa med par rnal 'byor legs par bsgoms pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The eighth is called “nirvāṇa” because it is the excellent meditation of yoga on the non-arising and non-ceasing of all phenomena.

original: dgu pa ni de bzhin nyid dang / chos kyi dbyings dang / yang dag pa'i mtha' mnyam pa nyid kyi yang dag pa'i mtha'i ye shes brnyes pa'i phyir yongs su @20a *//🔽mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: dgu pa ni de bzhin nyid dang / chos kyi dbyings dang / yang dag pa'i mtha' mnyam pa nyid kyi yang dag pa'i mtha'i ye shes brnyes pa'i phyir yongs su @20a *//🔽mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The ninth is called “nirvāṇa” because it attains the wisdom of the limit of reality, the sameness of suchness, the dharma-constituent, and the limit of reality.

original: bcu pa ni chos rnams kyi ngo bo nyid dang / mya ngan las 'das pa'i ngo bo nyid la bye brag med pa brnyes pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya ste /
analyzed: bcu pa ni chos rnams kyi ngo bo nyid dang / mya ngan las 'das pa'i ngo bo nyid la bye brag med pa brnyes pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya ste /
translated: The tenth is called “nirvāṇa” because it is the attainment of the non-differentiation of the nature of phenomena and the nature of nirvāṇa.

original: rigs kyi bu /
analyzed: rigs kyi bu /
translated: Son of noble family,

original: 'di dag ni yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa yod par bstan pa'i chos rnam pa bcu zhes bya'o //
analyzed: 'di dag ni yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa yod par bstan pa'i chos rnam pa bcu zhes bya'o //
translated: these are called the ten teachings that demonstrate the existence of nirvāṇa.

original: gzhan yang rigs kyi bu /🔽byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams kyis 'di ltar yang chos rnam pa bcus de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi de kho na nyid kyi don gyi tshul gyis mthar phyin pa'i yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa
analyzed: gzhan yang rigs kyi bu / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams kyis 'di ltar yang chos rnam pa bcus de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi de kho na nyid kyi don gyi tshul gyis mthar phyin pa'i yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa
translated: Moreover, son of noble family,

original: chen po yod par gsungs pa gang yin pa shes par 'gyur bar rig par bya'o //
analyzed: chen po yod par gsungs pa gang yin pa shes par 'gyur bar rig par bya'o //
translated: the bodhisattva mahāsattvas should understand that the tathāgata, the arhat, the perfectly enlightened buddha has taught the existence of the great nirvāṇa that is the ultimate meaning of suchness through ten dharmas.

original: bcu gang zhe na /
analyzed: bcu gang zhe na /
translated: What are the ten?

original: dang po ni nyon mongs pa thams cad ni 'dod pas gzhi byas pa yin pas 'dod pa las skyes pa yin la sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni 'dod pa yongs su bcad pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: dang po ni nyon mongs pa thams cad ni 'dod pas gzhi byas pa yin pas 'dod pa las skyes pa yin la sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni 'dod pa yongs su bcad pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The first is that since all afflictions are based on desire, they are born from desire. The transcendent buddhas are called “totally liberated” because they have eliminated desire.

original: gnyis pa ni de bzhin gshegs pa rnams nyon mongs pa'i 'dod pa rnams yongs su bcad pas chos 'ga' yang len par mi mdzad la /
analyzed: gnyis pa ni de bzhin gshegs pa rnams nyon mongs pa'i 'dod pa rnams yongs su bcad pas chos 'ga' yang len par mi mdzad la /
translated: The second is that since the tathāgatas have eliminated the desire of the afflictions, they do not take up any phenomenon.

original: len par mi mdzad pa'i phyir gshegs pa'ang mi mnga' byon pa yang mi mnga' zhing len pa mi mnga' @20b pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: len par mi mdzad pa'i phyir gshegs pa'ang mi mnga' byon pa yang mi mnga' zhing len pa mi mnga' @20b pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: Because they do not take up anything, they do not go and they do not come. Because they do not take up anything, they are called “totally liberated.”

original: gsum pa ni 'di ltar de bzhin gshegs pa la gshegs pa dang / byon pha mi mnga' zhing len pa mi mnga' ba gang yin pa de ni chos kyi sku skye ba med cing 'gag pa med pa yin pas skye ba dang / 'gag pa med par gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: gsum pa ni 'di ltar de bzhin gshegs pa la gshegs pa dang / byon pha mi mnga' zhing len pa mi mnga' ba gang yin pa de ni chos kyi sku skye ba med cing 'gag pa med pa yin pas skye ba dang / 'gag pa med par gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The third is as follows: The Tathāgata’s going and coming are not found, and that which is not found is the unarisen and unceasing Dharma Body. Therefore, because of being unarisen and unceasing, it is called “nirvāṇa.”

original: bzhi pa ni skye ba dang / 'gag pa med pa gang yin pa de ni tshig gis brjod par bya ba ma yin te tshig gi lam yongs su chad par gyur ba'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: bzhi pa ni skye ba dang / 'gag pa med pa gang yin pa de ni tshig gis brjod par bya ba ma yin te tshig gi lam yongs su chad par gyur ba'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The fourth is as follows: That which is unarisen and unceasing is not to be expressed verbally, because the verbal path is cut off. Therefore, it is called “nirvāṇa.”

original: lnga pa ni bdag dang / gang zag med kyi chos tsam 'ba' zhig skye 'gag tu gyur pa'i gnas su gyur pa brnyes pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: lnga pa ni bdag dang / gang zag med kyi chos tsam 'ba' zhig skye 'gag tu gyur pa'i gnas su gyur pa brnyes pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The fifth is as follows: There is no self and no person, and only mere phenomena arise and cease. Because the state of having attained that is found, it is called “nirvāṇa.”

original: drug pa ni nyon mongs pa dang / nye ba'i nyon mongs pa gang yin pa de dag thams cad ni glo bur gyi rdul yin la chos nyid gang yin pa de ni bdag po yin te /
analyzed: drug pa ni nyon mongs pa dang / nye ba'i nyon mongs pa gang yin pa de dag thams cad ni glo bur gyi rdul yin la chos nyid gang yin pa de ni bdag po yin te /
translated: The sixth is that all afflictions and branch afflictions are adventitious stains, while the dharmatā is the nature.

original: 'gro ba med cing 'ong ba med par sangs rgyas rnams kyis thugs su chud pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: 'gro ba med cing 'ong ba med par sangs rgyas rnams kyis thugs su chud pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: Because the buddhas have realized that there is no coming or going, it is called “nirvāṇa.”

original: bdun pa ni de bzhin nyid gang yin pa de ni yang dag pa yin la gzhan thams cad ni yang dag pa ma yin pas yang dag pa'i ngo bo nyid gang yin pa de ni de bzhin nyid yin la /🔽de bzhin nyid kyi ngo bo nyid gang yin pa de ni de bzhin gshegs pa yin pas yongs @21a *//
analyzed: bdun pa ni de bzhin nyid gang yin pa de ni yang dag pa yin la gzhan thams cad ni yang dag pa ma yin pas yang dag pa'i ngo bo nyid gang yin pa de ni de bzhin nyid yin la / de bzhin nyid kyi ngo bo nyid gang yin pa de ni de bzhin gshegs pa yin pas yongs @21a *//
translated: The seventh is that suchness is real, while everything else is unreal. Therefore, the essence of reality is suchness.

original: su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: Because the essence of suchness is the Tathāgata, it is called “nirvāṇa.”

original: brgyad pa ni yang dag pa'i mtha'i ngo bo nyid gang yin pa de la ni spros pa med de /
analyzed: brgyad pa ni yang dag pa'i mtha'i ngo bo nyid gang yin pa de la ni spros pa med de /
translated: The eighth is that the essence of the perfect limit is free from mental proliferation.

original: de bzhin gshegs pa nyag cig gis yang dag pa'i mtha'i chos mngon sum du gyur nas spros pa gtan du bcad pas na /
analyzed: de bzhin gshegs pa nyag cig gis yang dag pa'i mtha'i chos mngon sum du gyur nas spros pa gtan du bcad pas na /
translated: The Tathāgata alone, having directly realized the dharmas of the very limit of reality, has cut off all elaborations.

original: yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: Therefore, he is said to have “attained complete nirvāṇa.”

original: dgu pa ni skye ba med pa gang yin pa de ni yang dag pa yin la /
analyzed: dgu pa ni skye ba med pa gang yin pa de ni yang dag pa yin la /
translated: The ninth is that which is non-arisen is real,

original: skye ba gang yin pa de ni mi bden pa yin pas byis pa blun po rnams 'khor bar bying zhing 'dod pas khyer ba yin no /
analyzed: skye ba gang yin pa de ni mi bden pa yin pas byis pa blun po rnams 'khor bar bying zhing 'dod pas khyer ba yin no /
translated: and that which is arisen is not real. Therefore, foolish, confused beings sink in saṃsāra and are carried away by desire.

original: de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku la ni yang dag par mi bden pa mi mnga' bas yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku la ni yang dag par mi bden pa mi mnga' bas yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The Tathāgata’s body does not have what is not real, and therefore he is said to have “attained complete nirvāṇa.”

original: bcu pa ni yang dag pa'i chos ma yin pa gang yin pa de ni rkyen las byung ba yin la /
analyzed: bcu pa ni yang dag pa'i chos ma yin pa gang yin pa de ni rkyen las byung ba yin la /
translated: The tenth is that which is not a real dharma arises from conditions,

original: yang dag pa'i chos gang yin pa de ni rkyen las byung ba ma yin te /
analyzed: yang dag pa'i chos gang yin pa de ni rkyen las byung ba ma yin te /
translated: and that which is a real dharma does not arise from conditions.

original: de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos kyi sku'i ngo bo nyid gang yin pa de ni yang dag pa yin pas yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos kyi sku'i ngo bo nyid gang yin pa de ni yang dag pa yin pas yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The essence of the Tathāgata’s dharmakāya is real, and therefore it is called “nirvāṇa.”

original: rigs kyi bu /
analyzed: rigs kyi bu /
translated: Son of noble family,

original: 'di dag ni yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa yod par bstan pa'i chos rnam pa bcu zhes bya'o //
analyzed: 'di dag ni yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa yod par bstan pa'i chos rnam pa bcu zhes bya'o //
translated: these are called the ten teachings that demonstrate the existence of nirvāṇa.

original: gzhan yang / rigs kyi bu /🔽byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams kyi 'di ltar yang chos rnam pa bcus de bzhin gshegs pa yang dag par rdzogs @21b pa'i sangs rgyas kyi de kho na nyid kyi don gyi tshul gyis mthar phyin pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa chen po yod par
analyzed: gzhan yang / rigs kyi bu / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams kyi 'di ltar yang chos rnam pa bcus de bzhin gshegs pa yang dag par rdzogs @21b pa'i sangs rgyas kyi de kho na nyid kyi don gyi tshul gyis mthar phyin pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa chen po yod par
translated: Moreover, son of noble family,

original: gsungs ba gang yin par shes par 'gyur bar rig par bya'o //
analyzed: gsungs ba gang yin par shes par 'gyur bar rig par bya'o //
translated: you should know that in this way, through ten aspects, the tathāgatas, the genuinely fully awakened buddhas, have taught that the great nirvāṇa that is the finality of reality exists.

original: bcu gang zhe na /
analyzed: bcu gang zhe na /
translated: What are these ten?

original: dang po ni de bzhin gshegs pas sbyin pa dang / sbyin pa'i 'bras bu la bdag dang / bdag gi ba med par legs par thugs su chud pas sbyin pa dang / sbyin pa'i 'bras bu de la log par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: dang po ni de bzhin gshegs pas sbyin pa dang / sbyin pa'i 'bras bu la bdag dang / bdag gi ba med par legs par thugs su chud pas sbyin pa dang / sbyin pa'i 'bras bu de la log par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The first is called “nirvana” because the Tathagata has fully understood that generosity and the result of generosity are devoid of “I” and “mine,” and because he has attained peace by completely eliminating all false notions about generosity and the result of generosity.

original: gnyis pa ni de bzhin gshegs pas tshul khrims dang / tshul khrims kyi 'bras bu bdag dang / bdag gi ba med par legs par thugs su chud pas tshul khrims dang / tshul khrims kyi 'bras bu de la logs par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: gnyis pa ni de bzhin gshegs pas tshul khrims dang / tshul khrims kyi 'bras bu bdag dang / bdag gi ba med par legs par thugs su chud pas tshul khrims dang / tshul khrims kyi 'bras bu de la logs par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The second is called “nirvana” because the Tathagata has fully understood that morality and the result of morality are devoid of “I” and “mine,” and because he has attained peace by completely eliminating all false notions about morality and the result of morality.

original: gsum pa ni de bzhin gshegs pas bzod pa dang / bzod pa'i 'bras bu la bdag dang / bdag gi ba med par legs par thugs chud pas bzod pa dang / bzod pa'i 'bras bu de la log par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //🔽bzhi pa ni de bzhin gshegs pas brtson 'grus dang / brtson 'grus kyi 'bras bu la bdag dang / bdag gi ba med @22a *//
analyzed: gsum pa ni de bzhin gshegs pas bzod pa dang / bzod pa'i 'bras bu la bdag dang / bdag gi ba med par legs par thugs chud pas bzod pa dang / bzod pa'i 'bras bu de la log par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o // bzhi pa ni de bzhin gshegs pas brtson 'grus dang / brtson 'grus kyi 'bras bu la bdag dang / bdag gi ba med @22a *//
translated: The third is the nirvana of the Tathagata, because he has fully understood patience and the result of patience to be devoid of self and what belongs to self, and because he has fully eliminated all false views regarding patience and the result of patience and has attained peace.

original: par thugs su chud pas brtson 'grus dang / brtson 'grus kyi 'bras bu de la log par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: par thugs su chud pas brtson 'grus dang / brtson 'grus kyi 'bras bu de la log par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The fourth is the nirvana of the Tathagata, because he has fully understood effort and the result of effort to be devoid of self and what belongs to self, and because he has fully eliminated all false views regarding effort and the result of effort and has attained peace.

original: lnga pa ni de bzhin gshegs pas bsam gtan dang / bsam gtan gyi 'bras bu la bdag dang / bdag gi ba med par thugs su chud pas bsam gtan dang / bsam gtan gyi 'bras bu de la log par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: lnga pa ni de bzhin gshegs pas bsam gtan dang / bsam gtan gyi 'bras bu la bdag dang / bdag gi ba med par thugs su chud pas bsam gtan dang / bsam gtan gyi 'bras bu de la log par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The fifth is the transcendence of suffering, because the Tathāgata has fully understood that the meditative development of the factors that contribute to enlightenment and the result of the meditative development of the factors that contribute to enlightenment are devoid of self and what belongs to a self and, having fully understood this, he has attained peace by virtue of the complete relinquishment of all false view in regard to the meditative development of the factors that contribute to enlightenment and the result of the meditative development of the factors that contribute to enlightenment.

original: drug pa ni de bzhin gshegs pas shes rab dang / shes rab kyi 'bras bu la bdag dang / bdag gi ba med par legs par thugs su chud pas shes rab dang / shes rab kyi 'bras bu de la log par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: drug pa ni de bzhin gshegs pas shes rab dang / shes rab kyi 'bras bu la bdag dang / bdag gi ba med par legs par thugs su chud pas shes rab dang / shes rab kyi 'bras bu de la log par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The sixth is the transcendence of suffering, because the Tathāgata has fully understood that wisdom and the result of wisdom are devoid of self and what belongs to a self and, having fully understood this, he has attained peace by virtue of the complete relinquishment of all false view in regard to wisdom and the result of wisdom.

original: bdun pa ni de bzhin gshegs pas sems can dang  sems can ma yin pa thams cad dang / chos thams cad la ngo bo nyid med pa thugs su chud pas log par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: bdun pa ni de bzhin gshegs pas sems can dang  sems can ma yin pa thams cad dang / chos thams cad la ngo bo nyid med pa thugs su chud pas log par rtog pa gtan du bsal nas zhi bar gyur pa'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The seventh is that the Tathāgatas have realized that all sentient beings and insentient things, and all things, have no intrinsic reality, and so they have completely eliminated false imagination and attained peace, and for that reason it is called “nirvāṇa.

original: brgyad pa ni gang gis bdag nyid la sred cing mngon par zhen pa de ni yongs su tshol bar byed pa la @22b yongs su tshol ba'i phyir ni sdug bsngal mang po myong bar 'gyur ba yin na /
analyzed: brgyad pa ni gang gis bdag nyid la sred cing mngon par zhen pa de ni yongs su tshol bar byed pa la @22b yongs su tshol ba'i phyir ni sdug bsngal mang po myong bar 'gyur ba yin na /
translated: The eighth is that those who crave and cling to a self seek it, and because of seeking it, they experience much suffering.

original: de bzhin gshegs pa rnams ni bdag nyid la sred pa spangs pa'i phyir yongs su tshol ba gtan du bcad de yongs su tshol ba mi mnga' ba'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: de bzhin gshegs pa rnams ni bdag nyid la sred pa spangs pa'i phyir yongs su tshol ba gtan du bcad de yongs su tshol ba mi mnga' ba'i phyir yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The Tathāgatas have abandoned craving for a self, and so they have completely eliminated seeking, and because they do not seek, it is called “nirvāṇa.”

original: dgu pa ni 'dus byas kyi chos thams cad ni grangs dang / tshad yod pa yin la 'dus ma byas kyi chos gang yin pa de ni grangs dang; tshad spangs pa yin te /
analyzed: dgu pa ni 'dus byas kyi chos thams cad ni grangs dang / tshad yod pa yin la 'dus ma byas kyi chos gang yin pa de ni grangs dang; tshad spangs pa yin te /
translated: The ninth is that all conditioned phenomena have numbers and measures, but whatever is an unconditioned phenomenon is beyond number and measure.

original: rigs kyi bu /
analyzed: rigs kyi bu /

analyzed: 'di ltar de bzhin gshegs pa rnams byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis mngon par rtogs pa thob par bya ba'i phyir dang / don dam pa'i bden pa bstan nas 'khor ba dang / mya ngan las 'das pa ro gcig pa nyid du shes par bya ba'i phyir dang /
translated: Thus, the tathāgatas teach the ultimate truth in order that bodhisattvas may attain realization, in order that they may understand that saṃsāra and nirvāṇa are of one taste,🔽in order to dispel the view of the transitory composite and generate fear and delight,

original: 'jig tshogs la lta ba yongs su bsal nas 'jigs shing skrag pa dang / rab tu dga' ba bskyed pa'i phyir dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos mtha' med pa'i gzhi mdzad pa'i phyir dang / yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du de bzhin nyid dang /

translated: in order to establish the limitless qualities of a buddha, and in order that they may understand suchness just as it is.

original: de bzhin nyid kyi ye shes dang / sngon gyi smon lam gyi stobs dang rjes su mthun par mdzad pa'i phyir sku gang gis mtshan sum cu rtsa gnyis dang / dpe byad bzang po brgyad cu phun sum tshogs pa dang / dbu dang / rgyab kyi 'od yongs su rdzogs pa ston pa gang yin pa de ni longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sku zhes bya'o //
analyzed: de bzhin nyid kyi ye shes dang / sngon gyi smon lam gyi stobs dang rjes su mthun par mdzad pa'i phyir sku gang gis mtshan sum cu rtsa gnyis dang / dpe byad bzang po brgyad cu phun sum tshogs pa dang / dbu dang / rgyab kyi 'od yongs su rdzogs pa ston pa gang yin pa de ni longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sku zhes bya'o //
translated: The body that displays the thirty-two major marks and eighty minor marks of a great being, as well as the complete light of the head and back, is called the body of enjoyment.

original: rigs kyi bu /
analyzed: rigs kyi bu /
translated: Son of noble family,

translated: how should bodhisattva mahāsattvas understand the dharmakāya?

original: nyon mongs pa'i sgrib pa la sogs pa yongs su bsal nas dge ba'i chos rnams yongs su rdzogs par gyur pa'i phyir de bzhin nyid kyi ye shes kho na nyid dang ldan par gyur pa gang yin pa de ni chos kyi sku zhes bya'o //

translated: The wisdom of suchness, which is endowed with the complete elimination of the afflictive and cognitive obscurations and the complete perfection of virtuous qualities, is called the dharmakāya.

original: sku snga ma rnam pa gnyis ni btags pa tsam du yod pa yin la /
analyzed: sku snga ma rnam pa gnyis ni btags pa tsam du yod pa yin la /
translated: The two previous bodies exist merely as imputations.

original: sku gsum pa 'di ni yang dag par yod pa yin te /

analyzed: sku snga ma gnyis kyi rtsa bar gyur pa'i phyir ro //
translated: because it is the root of the former two bodies.

original: de ci'i phyir zhe na /
analyzed: de ci'i phyir zhe na /
translated: Why is this?

original: chos kyi de bzhin nyid dang / rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes ma gtogs par sangs rgyas thams cad las gud na chos gzhan mi mnga' ste /
analyzed: chos kyi de bzhin nyid dang / rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes ma gtogs par sangs rgyas thams cad las gud na chos gzhan mi mnga' ste /
translated: Apart from the suchness of phenomena and nonconceptual wisdom, there is no other phenomenon apart from all buddhas.

original: sangs rgyas thams cad ni mkhyen pa phun sum tshogs par gyur na nyon mongs pa thams cad gtan du nye bar zhi zhing zad nas sangs rgyas kyi sa rnam par dag pa brnyes par 'gyur bas /

translated: When all buddhas have perfected omniscience, all afflictions are completely pacified and exhausted, and they attain the pure stage of buddhahood.

original: de'i phyir chos kyi de bzhin nyid dang / de bzhin nyid kyi ye shes ni sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad yongs su sdud par 'gyur ro //
analyzed: de'i phyir chos kyi de bzhin nyid dang / de bzhin nyid kyi ye shes ni sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad yongs su sdud par 'gyur ro //
translated: Therefore, the suchness of phenomena and the wisdom of suchness encompass all the qualities of buddhahood.

original: gzhan yang / rigs kyi bu /
analyzed: gzhan yang / rigs kyi bu /
translated: Moreover, son of noble family,

original: sangs rgyas thams cad ni bdag dang / gzhan la phan 'dogs pa'i mthar byon pa yin pas /
